zuul/connection/__init__.py.message:
All of the connections seem to use the same branch cache. Why do we need to set it externally in this case?

Is this due to the tenant validation case which is mentioned in a comment below?

It's startup process: we instantiate connectors without a scheduler, so no zk client available.

This mirrors the change cache as well; so all connections use both caches and they're initialized the same way.

zuul/zk/branch_cache.py.message: Nit this is from existing code terminology but it might be a bit more readable if we made this more positive rather than negative flag? Something like "only_protected".
Probably so.  But this extends into the tenant config file, so we're probably best to stick with it at this point for consistency unless we want to make a user-facing deprecation.
We have a read lock but we don't use it here. Should we?

Do we not need to set protected_branches in this case too?

It seems the way we've done this we must set branches excluding unprotected first. Then we can set branches a second time setting the unprotected branches. Otherwise we won't have a complete cohesive picture. I worry that this might end up leading to errors and if we can make it more atomic that would be better.

The new tests seem to confirm this behavior as the second half of the test does a query which matches None for protected branches then a query for unprotected which matches all branches. Essentially we have protected branches but we can't get them back at that point?

Yeah, this is pretty twisted code, but it's all in service of two goals:
1) Be able to answer both of these questions independently:
   a) What is the full list of branches for the repo?
   b) What is list of protected branches for the repo?
2) Store that data efficiently in ZK.

The old code only had the first constraint, so it actually just stored two dictionaries that were completely independent (basically, two caches in one code base).  But it duplicated thet data between the two.  I have trouble convincing myself that doing that in ZK is desirable, so the complexity here is trying to fulfill #1 without that data structure.

To do that, we can obviously have a list of protected branches, then the list of the rest of the branches, and add the two together to answer 1.a.

But we have no idea whether the system will be asking for 1.a, or 1.b, or both.  And if it's both, we don't know what order.  That's because two tenants can have the same project in them with different exclude-unprotected-branches settings.

So the code here is designed to handle any of those cases.  If we narrow down the question for the code after the else on line 143, we know that the system is currently dealing with the response to a query for all branches.  We have the following possibilities:

A) We already have a cached list of protected branches.  In this case, we take our list of all branches, subtract the protected branches from it, and store the remainder in the remainder field.
B) We don't hove a list of protected branches (or it's empty).  All branches are remainder branches in that case.

That sets us up for the following possibilities for a consumer in a future "get" call to the cache:

I) The call is for all branches.  In either A or B above, we configured the cache so that protected+remainder will return all, so that's what we return.
II) The call is for protected branches.  In this case there are two possibilities (and we need to refer to getProjectBranches to see this tree):
    i) self.cache.protected[project_name] is None.  In this case we have never performed an exclude-unprotected query, so we don't have the data.  We return None and the caller performs the query and updates the cache (thereby triggering the first part of the if/else in this method to update the cache in the mirror of what we've done here so far).
    ii) self.cache.protected[project_name] is not None.  In this case, we have data, so that's what we return.

Because of I.i, we need to make sure not to set self.cache.protected unless we have actual data.

tl;dr: a cache value of None means we haven't performed that type of query, and this cache is supposed to mutate in both directions.
This was very helpful thank you.

This is adding the expiring-soon to ignore list. The alarm can be raised for any entity. Is this checking against the entity id?

Same goes for expired alarm. Expired alarm can be raised against any entity.

The ignore list (at this level) does not have filtering by internal values.
It basically would just blanket-ignore any alarms of this type when determining if the system is sane enough to exercise this operation.
If the underlying cause for that alarm ends up blocking an action later, we would just report that failure when it happens.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: Maybe we should add fm_constants.FM_ALARM_ID_CERT_EXPIRED also? Guess a case in which the current procedure will be triggered while the above alarm is raised is a valid one...

Hi John,

According to the bug report the scenario we are considering here is when the user generates a new rootca that is expiring soon, which is a possible and valid case, as opposed to generating an expired certificate, which is not allowed on `kube-rootca-update-generate-cert` neither a valid use case given that it disrupts the communication with the cluster.
Ack

I think it's fine to add the expiring soon alarm here. But I think we need to add this alarm to the ignore list in the start request as well, to cover the case where the alarm already raised before update start. This would be a normal use case where the user get the expiring soon alarm, and he starts to update the cert.

Rafael, can you do some tests to see if adding "-f" will force the update complete successfully? I don't think the Jira reporter tried "-f" to complete.

Good catch regarding ignoring the alarm on the update start as well Andy, updated.

Regarding forcing the complete command, you are right: using the -f here forces the update to complete successfully even with the expiring soon alarm engaged.

I would suggest adding the 'expired'  at the same time.   I dont know for certain if that is critical or not, but the VIM has started suppressing it, so if it does block anything it will be later on.
As Sabeel indicated,  these alarms can be raised for multiple certificate types.

Having an un-related certificate expiring or expired  probably should not block us from being able to run operations here.

While I agree that it is not ideal to ignore unrelated expiring certificates here I think we should drive our discussion based on the purpose of the design of these checks, which can be interpreted as 'verify the system is healthy when starting the process and that it finishes as healthy as it was before'.

With that in mind, I don't think that having an expired cert on the system fits in these requirements, especially if this expired cert is the root CA one, given that the cluster connection is damaged and this procedure cannot be executed.
Ack

would the 'complete' procedure be able to run with an expired cert.  ie:  a person detects they are expiring,  perform most of the operations, and then forget to do the final stage.  I would assume at that point,  cert-alarm would no longer raise an expired anyways
Yes, you're correct: the alarm is removed during the `system kube-rootca-host-update host --phase=trust-new-ca` command.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Any reason why you're not fixing the internal garbage collection mechanism?

This commit is definitely just a mitigation of the issue before we understand the underlying cause.  I think it's worth to note that other runtimes (eg. crio) have reported a similar issue(s) somewhat recently.

I'm a bit confused by the above two paragraphs.  Is this an accurate description or is it doing something else:
Every 6 hours the cleanup script analyzes the cache files by name and compares them with the id(s) of the currently running pods.  Any stale files detected which are over a day old are deleted.

Is every 6 hours overkill?  Would once per day suffice?  Any reason for 6 hours?

Yeah, this comment is a bit wrong.  Currently, the script will run every 6 hours and delete (stale) files that are over 6 hours old.  6 hours is _probably_ overkill, but it really depends on the nature of the size of the deployment and the instances that can lead to the stale files.  I'm aware of an instance of a system running for about a year and building up gigs of stale cache files.  In my case, I can only seem to reproduce the issue by doing a reboot.  Setting the cycle to 1 day or more would probably work, I'm definitely open to changing this depending on what people think.

I think I'm in agreement with you Steve. 6 hours is probably overkill for a stable long-running system. I think I'd go with a daily cleanup and maybe a one-shot service at startup to handle a node that is potentially stuck in a reboot loop that could cause these cache files to rapidly accumulate. The k8s pod recovery-service could be used call this script on startup after it's gone through the pod recovery steps.
Need some kind of test/verification section.
Ack

Perhaps you want to leave out the frequency and age of files deleted here as the frequency is controlled outside of this commit and the age of the files is specified through an option.  The commit which sets up the call to the script is probably the right place for this info ie. the sister puppet commit.
Ack

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Make sure you test every possible path in your script and also look at testing possible situations where your variables get set to nothing ie. "" and make sure the script doesn't just crap out.

kubernetes/k8s-cni-cache-cleanup/centos/.message: The above two separate crictl calls may produce different results as it races with other stuff that affects pod existence.  This could be an issue if you expect alignment between the PODIDS and PODNAMES variables.  You might have to call crictl once and put the output into a tempfile that you then can grep multiple times.
You really should get into the habit of wrapping all variables with {} eg. ${file}
Yeah, it looks like you assume a one to one mapping between podids and podnames in those arrays, see my note about race conditions earlier.
OLDERTHAN is just set to nothing ie. no default.  Does the script behave sanely if the -o option isn't given?

It does behave sanely, but I've set the default OLDERTHAN to 1 hour in the latest PS.  The reason being is that there _are_ periodic pod creation/deletions (example for the system pods are the ceph-pools-audit pods).  So in that case, it's possible in very rare cases/timings that this script would delete the cache files before the regular runtime cleanup if it was run without the -o flag.  Having said that, I have done testing on systems where the script has run consecutively at a rapid rate and deleted stale files before the runtime had a chance to perform this itself, and saw no negative effects on the system.  It seems the runtime cache cleanup is 'best effort' and does not appear to care if the cache files have been cleaned up.  However, I would rather just get out of the way of that as much as possible and only clean what has been dropped on the floor.

Well this is what I was getting at in the last revision. Tempest init will make a shim config file (or overwrite a couple options if it already exists) that sets some basics options:

https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/cmd/init.py#L92-L104

which is how you want things set in a workspace normally. (so it's logs are self contained and the locks don't conflict with any other running tempests) If we just do a cp $TEMPEST_CONFIG to $TEMPEST_WORKSPACE this would overwrite those settings. You can't have a config file in a workspace's local etc/ before you create a workspace. The only options here are to either bite the bullet and overwrite the config file (and probably manually change the log file and lock path) or use /etc/tempest/tempest.conf.

Tempest init will as an early step copy anything in a global config dir (which is found via: https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/cmd/init.py#L40-L64) into $TEMPEST_WORKSPACE/etc. So if you put the devstack generated tempest.config in /etc/tempest/tempest.config when you create the workspace with tempest init the config will already be there (and modified to put artifacts in the right place)
Whoops, this needs to happen before I run the init command, not after.

What will happen is when someone tries to use tempest the old way (straight from the repo) is that they'll end up with all of their logs and state artifacts stored in the workspace instead of here. Which I imagine would be confusing. But until we un-WIP this I think we should leave it just to make debugging easier

The problem here is that you are applying a pod security context at the container level.
If you want pod security context you need to apply it about at line 67.
You can also apply container level security contexts if you want. there is also a helm toolkit for that called kubernetes_container_security_context.
Also, the indentation is important here. for pod level security context in this file, you need indentation of 6. For container level security context you need indentation of 10.

pod:

          readOnlyRootFilesystem: <val>
        <container_name2>:

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This is with ro multiattach volumes right as rw multiattach volume swap is blocked as of Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778 ?

I've been working on this today and I don't think this write up of the bug is correct. What I think you're seeing is the following.

During a volume migration orchestrated by Cinder the original volume UUID is retained by Cinder merging the volume records leaving just the original volume at the end of the migration.

During the migration the connection_info for the new volume stored by Nova is gathered from Cinder prior to this and I believe references the temporary volume created by Cinder as part of the migration in your case.

This is different to a Nova orchestrated swap volume request that moves from one volume to another with the original removed. 

As a result of this during the next migration attempt the lookup code within nova.virt.block_device.get_volume_id finds this now deleted volume UUID in the connection_info and passes it to _should_disconnect_target. This UUID is then used to lookup the volume causing the VolumeNotFound failure.

I'll write up a functional test to show what I'm suggesting here but you should be able to prove this by reproducing in your env and checking the stashed connection_info after the initial migration.
I think this is not WIP any more

Inventory (just for note - default kolla-ansible inventory using mariadb without :children, but below is equivalent of all server in group [mariadb])

Scenrario 1 - two shards/clusters (first ids not defined, other defined)

[mariadb:children]
mariadb-cluster-regionOne
mariadb-cluster-regionTwo

[mariadb-cluster-regionOne]
server1
server2                        (no shard_id defined - typical kolla-ansible intentory)
server3

[mariadb-cluster-regionTwo]
server4 shard_id=2
server5 shard_id=2
server6 shard_id=2

Scenario 2 - two shards explicitly defined shard id in all shards/clusters

[mariadb:children]
mariadb-cluster-regionOne
mariadb-cluster-regionTwo

[mariadb-cluster-regionOne]
server1 shard_id=1
server2 shard_id=1
server3 shard_id=1

[mariadb-cluster-regionTwo]
server4 shard_id=2
server5 shard_id=2
server6 shard_id=2

So, role is functional only if there is shard_id defined, but there is an edge case (actually default behaviour for most users - to not define any shard_id host variable). Because of this it is referenced in defaults/main.yml with default, in first scenario if var is not defined ..it's using default id, if it is defined ..it is available in role.

ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/main.yml.message: Instead use a |default in here. I.e., if the variable is not overridden for the host, use the role default.

Well, mariadb_shard_id was used because it is number. This number is then used in proxysql configuration to calculate proper groups ids. Then you can have several shards (clusters) of mariadb and accessible as one cluster. Unfortunatelly it's not merged yet :( -> https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/770215/46

> Yes, I wrote my suggestion already: use '| default("mariadb_shard_group")' right after the expression you already have. That should consume the role var in case it is otherwise not defined.

Well, how should it work? In your commit message for the refactoring, you said just add mariadb_shard_id to the hostvars and done it will automatically create the shards groups. When using the role mariadb_shard_group variable it will calculate the value from one host for all and so it will pick up the mariadb_shard_id for the running host, not for each host.
If we want to use `default()` we should say in the commit message or release note that if you want to use shards you should define the mariadb_shard_group in hostvars not mariadb_shard_id!
Hmm, fair point about mariadb_shard_id. Maybe some other core will have a better idea. For now let's assume we have to refactor as you suggested.
Yes, I wrote my suggestion already: use '| default("mariadb_shard_group")' right after the expression you already have. That should consume the role var in case it is otherwise not defined.

> Instead use a |default in here. I.e., if the variable is not overridden for the host, use the role default.

If the vars were defined at the role level they were not available in hostvars. also, add_host will run on one host and mariadb_shard_group value will be for the running host. Do you have any better solution?
This approach would need to use run_once.

With variables movement to group_vars and task below everything will work OK also with limit, tested. 

- name: Group MariaDB hosts based on shards
  vars:
    mariadb_shard_id: "{{ hostvars[item]['mariadb_shard_id'] | default(mariadb_default_database_shard_id) }}"
  add_host:
    name: "{{ item }}"
    groups: "{{ mariadb_shard_group }}"
  with_items: "{{ groups['mariadb'] }}"
  run_once: yes

Note: There has to be shard_id as it's used in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/770215/46 <- not merged (but hope it will be)
changed_when: false

My suggestion was to change the task variable, to use a different name than the shard variable. Also to reference directly the group variable. This approach would require the variables to be in group_vars, but that's not so bad.

- name: Group MariaDB hosts based on shards
  vars:
    other_mariadb_shard_group: "{{ hostvars[item]['mariadb_shard_group'] }}"
  add_host:
    name: "{{ item }}"
    groups: "{{ other_mariadb_shard_group }}"
  loop: "{{ groups['mariadb'] }}"
  run_once: true
  changed_when: false

As I said in previous comments, there is need to use shard_id because proxysql patches generating hostgroups into proxysql configuration , proxysql has integer ids - it's simpler to just use var than crop that information from group (if it will be changed in hostvar from id to group - so if there is need to have "id" , group doesn't makes sense)

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
@Radosław

Not sure what would be the difference between KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE and KOLLA_BRANCH_NAME. Why do we need both?

I've initially used KOLLA_GIT_BRANCH here:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/815043/1/doc/source/conf.py#121

but got this feedback (opposed to yours):

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/815043/comment/dc615628_30485ab3/

My proposal is to only have KOLLA_GIT_BRANCH (used both for kolla and kolla-ansible). And comment above the variable that full branch name should be specified, e.g. 'master', 'stable/victoria' etc.

I prefer this version instead of this less obvious workaround: if KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE != 'master': 'stable/{}'.format(KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE)

And completely remove KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE, since AFAIK it's not needed.

Agreed? If not, please describe in detail why both KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE and KOLLA_GIT_BRANCH are needed.
Well, then the names reflect the contents. You don't strictly need KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE except for the fact that it's easy to define without forgetting about stable/ prefix.

As I said, we don't *need* both but it's nice to be able to provide only the name and have logic in place to convert the release name to branch name. It is also what we have in kolla-build internally - we have dedicated vars to created stable-release and stable/release flavours of identifiers. You can have both in code and in the map only KOLLA_BRANCH_NAME (KOLLA_GIT_BRANCH is fine too, whichever you prefer really) if you prefer to. But having both there will not hurt either.

And another thing

KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE = openstackdocstheme.ext._get_series_name()

returns 'victoria', 'wallby' etc., then being turned into ``git clone --branch stable/victoria https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla`` - which is fine)

But on master it returns 'latest' and there no latest remote branch like:

git clone --branch latest https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla

Could do:

if KOLLA_OPENSTACK_RELEASE == 'latest':
    KOLLA_BRANCH_NAME = 'master'

which would give:

git clone --branch master https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla

which is fine. Should I do it like that?

Can you explain rationale more here?  If no nova-compute is in "down" state at this point, is there a scenario where some "extra" nova-compute may still appear shortly after?

This is interesting info, but if that's the reality on the ground, it does help explain the context of all these checks.  It may make sense to add all these rationale as a comment, or maybe like I suggest before, combine all these checks into simply

while ( "number of computes UP" < "expected computes" ) || ( "extra_wait" )
  do 
     wait
     check and update number of computes UP
     update "extra_wait" per logic
end
Per testing results, it's quite often that not all the compute nodes are present at the time this init script is being executed, regardless of the state. I believe the state is just up/down.

Please link to the commit and mention its subject as well. At first it was not obvious to me where this commit is. I found it after a quick search:

```
commit 11329e49959b ("drivers: net: xilinx_emaclite: remove arch limitation")
```

https://git.yoctoproject.org/cgit/cgit.cgi/linux-yocto/commit/?id=11329e49959befc57839cdcde6fdb139a626882a

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/stable/linux.git/commit/?id=18af77c50fede5b3fc22aa9f0a9b255a5c5285c9

Agreed. We typically list the repository name for anything which is not mainline, and then also include the short log just in case the commit ID changes (yes not likely but it does happen from time to time). So something like

"because of commit 11329e49959befc57839cdcde6fdb139a626882a [drivers: net: xilinx_emaclite: remove arch limitation] on https://git.yoctoproject.org/cgit/cgit.cgi/linux-yocto."

The added benefit of including the short log is as a reviewer I can often understand the change without even looking at the commit.

README.md.message: Not currently true. MicroStack's latest version is Ussuri in the beta channels
I propose combining this with the "On Rails" section

I strongly suggest removing this because volume support in a fully confined mode depends on the resolution of a non-trivial bug in snapd:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/snapd/+bug/1892895
https://github.com/snapcore/snapd/pull/8926#issuecomment-886915476 as I commented here, this is not something that can be fixed in an interface - it's a snapd core problem.

This affects cases besides LVM that depend on dynamically created block special files (e.g. iSCSI or Fibre Channel).
we can add it back when it becomes stable
We should think of changing this to have a Quick Start section. Requirements can be part of that as well as installation instructions.
These items seem out of place in comparison to the earlier items.
Can you elaborate more? This is a sub list of the services provided that make MicroStack comprehensive

All of this should be in the documentation. Duplicating documentation should be avoided. Also, in general, "less is more" when it comes to MicroStack. Specifically, a shorter Quickstart is much more appealing to new users IMO. What we're trying to do on this page is get people interested.

## Quickstart

To deploy and initialise MicroStack:

    sudo snap install microstack --devmode --beta
    sudo microstack init --auto --control

To launch an instance (output will include instance connection details):

    microstack launch cirros --name test

Connect to the instance:

    ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_microstack cirros@<ip-address>

## Documentation

See the [MicroStack documentation][microstack-docs] for detailed information on installation, customisation, and usage.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi, All

Could we create one new story for I/O scheduler performance tuning?  this one is to bug fix "daemon.log flooding with systemd-udevd: err error opening ATTR".

Thanks,
Jiping

I understand that BFQ is configurable with weight, but I don't see whether this connected to the "ionice" settings we used to have. In particular we had a severe IO combined with task interactive scheduling problem for ETCD, and we used combination of nice -19 and ionice settings to boost the priorities for ETCD critical process. Without kube-apiserver would have terrible response times, and ETCD would end up having timeout and warning messages and it cascades into bunch of problems.

To watch the performance of ETCD process, I used "schedtop" tool with a customized version (not yet in the repo), which looks at the IO scheduling delay (just like "iotop"), as well as "blocked_max" kernel metric per task. This effectively indicates a response time of processses.

A tuning exercise can be performed in conjunction with running heavy IO load, while watching the "blocked_max" or "bmax".  If ionice does not work, perhaps we need to do something specific with BFQ "weight" for the ETCD task, TBD.

https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/block/bfq-iosched.txt

Perhaps the per-process weight is still configured via ionice. WBN to configure this mechanism actually works. See this note:

Unless the cgroups interface is used (see "4. BFQ group scheduling"),
weights can be assigned to processes only indirectly, through I/O
priorities, and according to the relation:
weight = (IOPRIO_BE_NR - ioprio) * 10.

For example we are setting the CPU and IO-scheduling parameters for ETCD like this in service file:
Nice=-19
IOSchedulingClass=best-effort
IOSchedulingPriority=0
Just clean up the verification section and we're good.
Thanks you Jim for the detail review.

Hello Al and Bob,

Is there any chance that you could approve this patch? (I will send an e-mail to you as well, in case Gerrit's notifications are filtered.)

Thank you,

Vefa

io-scheduler/centos/files/60-io-schedule.message: The above comments appear to be useful and specific to our product, don't you want to preserve them?  I suggest looking up whoever wrote them (git blame?) and consult with them.  Note the last sentence "This setting requires re-evaluation with io-schedulers (i.e., mq-deadline, bfq, kyber) available in new kernels."  Since those new schedulers are now being used, has anyone done the i/o performance "re-evaluation"?  I can respect that you are getting rid of error messages as per the bug report, but is there a Story or Task to do this performance re-evaluation?  It should not fall through the cracks.

OK, I will leave the comments here.
I git log 60-io-scheduler.rules.  and find you modified this file. and add these comments. I do not know if there is any one do the i/o performance "re-evaluation". Can you give me some suggestion? is there any team can do the performance test?
Nimalini is the likely contact for i/o performance regression testing, but the issue still remains about tuning things should the performance fall short.
The MQ-DEADLINE also has these tunables. Probably need to see Linbit recommendation of these tunables for DRBD.  The deault write_expire is 5000 ms.
The BFQ scheduler has slice_idle parameter. cannot choose setting without doing latency/fairness study with actual heavy IO load and parallelism.

I would argue that the "default" is our previous settings, not the default linux setting. eg, the previous LinBit DRBD/SSD recommended values for deadline apply to mq-deadline (the same parameters exist and have the same meaning). Likewise, the previous CFQ tuning of slice_idle applies to BFQ.

Following this rationale, I would also not undo the tuning of critical process ETCD to nice 0, and undo its ionice for kernel 5.11. This tuned value was engineered this way for a reason based on actual behaviour.

Yes, I agree that cannot choose setting without doing latency/fairness study with actual heavy IO load and parallelism.  so we leave the default value for all the parameters.  and need our I/O scheduler performance regression test if the performance is accepted.
What happened to the quantum option?  Is it gone or did they replace it with something else?
Thanks Vefa.  We should probably just leave it to auto tune.

I took a look at BFQ I/O scheduler's tune-able settings, and the "timeout_sync" and "max_budget" options appear to have a similar effect to that of the CFQ I/O scheduler's "quantum" option.

StarlingX's defaults multiply CFQ's quantum option's default value with 4. That is: 8 requests -> 32 requests.

BFQ's "max_budget" is automatically tuned. We could override the auto-tuned "max_budget"s value and multiply its value with 4 at run-time, but perhaps it would be safer to increase "timeout_sync" (instead of disabling auto-tuning) as recommended by BFQ's documentation.

timeout_sync is currently set to HZ / 8 in the code:

```
/* Default timeout values, in jiffies, approximating CFQ defaults. */
const int bfq_timeout = HZ / 8;
```

If my understanding is correct, it corresponds to 1/8 seconds (in other words, 125 milliseconds):

```
controller-0:~$ sudo tee /sys/block/sda/queue/scheduler <<<bfq >/dev/null ; cat /sys/block/sda/queue/iosched/timeout_sync
125
```

We could multiply the value with 4 to set it to 500 milliseconds instead. I do not know if this would be a good idea though. We really need benchmarks.

Here is a quotation from BFQ's documentation:

```
timeout_sync
------------

Maximum amount of device time that can be given to a task (queue) once
it has been selected for service. On devices with costly seeks,
increasing this time usually increases maximum throughput. On the
opposite end, increasing this time coarsens the granularity of the
short-term bandwidth and latency guarantees, especially if the
following parameter is set to zero.

max_budget 
---------- 

Maximum amount of service, measured in sectors, that can be provided
to a BFQ queue once it is set in service (of course within the limits
of the above timeout). According to what said in the description of
the algorithm, larger values increase the throughput in proportion to
the percentage of sequential I/O requests issued. The price of larger
values is that they coarsen the granularity of short-term bandwidth
and latency guarantees.

The default value is 0, which enables auto-tuning: BFQ sets max_budget
to the maximum number of sectors that can be served during
timeout_sync, according to the estimated peak rate.

For specific devices, some users have occasionally reported to have
reached a higher throughput by setting max_budget explicitly, i.e., by
setting max_budget to a higher value than 0. In particular, they have
set max_budget to higher values than those to which BFQ would have set
it with auto-tuning. An alternative way to achieve this goal is to
just increase the value of timeout_sync, leaving max_budget equal to 0.
```

There is not this one in new kernel.

quantum
-------
This specifies the number of request dispatched to the device queue. In a
queue's time slice, a request will not be dispatched if the number of request
in the device exceeds this parameter. This parameter is used for synchronous
request.

In case of storage with several disk, this setting can limit the parallel
processing of request. Therefore, increasing the value can improve the
performance although this can cause the latency of some I/O to increase due
to more number of requests.

For reviewers,  python3 changed how rounding works.

In python 2
 round(2.5)  returns 3
 round(3.5)  returns 4
but in python3
 round(2.5)  returns 2 (different)
 round(3.5)  returns 4 

so this change makes the py2 and py3 code act the same

alternatively:
    return float(math.floor((number * param) + math.copysign(0.5, number))) / param

nova/db/api/migrations/env.py.message:
resource_providers

Also, what is the significance of this list of columns? I looked at the documentation [1] but unfortunately I still don't know what it means to "include a name" and why some columns should not include a name.

Is there a way to test this, to run this code such that we would have caught the typo? Should this have failed while running migrations?

[1] https://alembic.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/api/runtime.html#alembic.runtime.environment.EnvironmentContext.configure.params.include_name

> resource_providers

Oh, weird. I'm not sure how this is passing...

> Also, what is the significance of this list of columns? I looked at the documentation [1] but unfortunately I still don't know what it means to "include a name" and why some columns should not include a name.

These are the docs you're looking for:

https://alembic.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/autogenerate.html#controlling-what-to-be-autogenerated

tl;dr: the auto-generation stuff works by comparing the schema of an existing table which was created by alembic using the existing migrations, to the schema it expects for the models. The 'include_name' function is used to determine whether to consider an object (i.e. a given table, column, schema, etc.) in this comparison. We use this function to exclude the shadow tables when looking at the main table. These particular entries all correspond to columns that have been removed from the models but which we don't want to remove from the underlying database yet. I'll add a comment to communicate this better.
 
> Is there a way to test this, to run this code such that we would have caught the typo? Should this have failed while running migrations?
> 
> [1] https://alembic.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/api/runtime.html#alembic.runtime.environment.EnvironmentContext.configure.params.include_name

To generate this list, I simply attempted to auto-generate a migration as described in the docs [1]. You can do this yourself locally, if you want:

  $ tox -e venv -- alembic -c nova/db/api/alembic.ini upgrade head
  $ tox -e venv -- alembic -c nova/db/api/alembic.ini revision --autogenerate

Anything that popped up was included in this list, once I'd verified it wasn't a genuine mistake. To test this, we could write a test harness that calls the machinery that auto-generate is using under the hood to detect the same changes. There shouldn't be: if there are, our migrations are out of data. I'm not sure how to do that right now so I'll have to investigate.

Later: aaand after running the commands I gave above, I know the answer to my question up top: it wasn't working:

  $ tox -e venv -- alembic -c nova/db/api/alembic.ini revision --autogenerate
  ...
  INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Context impl SQLiteImpl.
  INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Will assume non-transactional DDL.
  INFO  [alembic.autogenerate.compare] Detected removed column 'resource_providers.can_host'
    Generating /home/stephenfin/Development/openstack/nova/nova/db/api/migrations/versions/4852bec199d8_.py ...  done

fat-fingers--

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/database-migrations.html#schema-migrations

Turns out we already do this. The oslo.db-based tests we've provided in [1] and [2] validate that migrations match models, and they have their own version of this "whitelist" of columns and tables that should be ignore. It seems we simply need to place this in a common place to avoid potential fat-fingering. I'll do that in a follow-up.

PS: I grokked this by reading zzzeek's comments at [3]

[1] nova/tests/unit/db/main/test_migrations.py
[2] nova/tests/unit/db/api/test_migrations.py
[3] https://github.com/sqlalchemy/alembic/issues/724#issuecomment-672081357

I've added the follow-up to move this to the common place [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/814489/1
++ thanks for the detailed code comment
